page.title: 12TRANSPORT ON THE BLACKWATER
page.content: Hundreds of years ago the Blackwater, which is deep enough to take big ships was very important to the prosperity of the area.In 1796 a canal was built which allowed goods to be transported by barge to Chelmsford. Coal,timber and fertilizer were transported into the area while hay and other farm produce was transported out.Barges used to collect grain from the farms in Mundon and deliver it to the mills along the river. At Iltney farm there is a disused canal which was built by Marriages to enable barges to collect the grain they needed from the local farmers. When the railway was built water transport lost its importance. The railway is now closed but the river has not benefited. Now farm produce is transported by road hauliers. by Raymond Warr 1B2
